course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Modern East Asia
course.description: This course is a survey of the history of political, social, economic, and cultural changes in East Asia (mainly China and Japan, and to some extent, Korea) from the 1800s to the 1950s. In the past two centuries, the classical civilizations of East Asia met new challenges: the disintegration of old political systems, the growth of social tensions, and the arrival of an aggressive and expanding West. This course will study the internal and external tensions that undermined the traditional orders, compelling China, Japan, and Korea to seek new political and social reforms. Special attention will be given to the revolutionary changes in society, thought, culture, and the rise of a new political order in twentieth-century China, Japan, and Korea.

reviews.author: KayC
reviews.title: Extremely heavy workload!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
focus on history of East Asia(mainly China) in the 19th and 20th century. Maybe current news in the first 20 mins.
recommend if interested in history.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good. His point is interesting and reflective. Greatly beneficial for knowing the world.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading under heavy workload I think.
Since there were not so many people in this course(maybe more than 20), and the A range is about 30%, maybe it's a a little bit hard to get A range.
My midterm and midterm essay is around B+ level. I did't hand in the optional documentary but get a A- in the end.(no idea about other final works.)
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely heavy workload!!!!!!
reading materials and documentary
10 timelines and summary (almost every week!)
midterm exam and midterm essay
due to the special situation, no final exams but project(including outline of it), final essay, combined timeline, book/film review!
optional documentary

reviews.author: AnnaVii
reviews.title: A fantastic course
reviews.comment_content:
The professor takes you through China's history. There is a brief introduction to how the nation was formed and its relationship with other Asia countries and the West.

After giving you some background you take a deep dive into what happened in the 1800th hundred to the present. For students with no background in Chinese politics, history, and culture it is a very fun course to take. It can be considered heavy if you really want to learn every detail and causation between historic actors and events. However, by attending class and taking a few notes you will get the grasp of it.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is super knowledgeable and will happily answer your questions. He talks a lot in class so afterwards you may feel a bit overwhelmed by the information overload( good to take some notes so you remember the crucial parts). The medium of teaching varies ppt, simple talk, videos, photos, discussion.
reviews.comment_grading: I got an A and I remember I put in quite the effort for the final project. Overall, I think you will get a decent grade by attending class, participating, and writing fairly enthusiastic in your homework.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly homework: write a timeline of events thaught in that week

Midterm exam: cover content, actors, events if first half of semester

Final exam: covers the latter part of the semester

Project: write and interview a person who experienced China during some crucial event. Ex. Your grandma might live through a war China had with some country. Interview her and get her perspective of it, along with gathering facts about it. Here you need to put in the effort to get a good grade( if that is important to you)

reviews.author: xDDD
reviews.title: Easy and intersting
reviews.comment_content: Focused on East asian history, with a focus on Chinese History after the fall of the Qing Dynasty. Talked about different forces that lead to the formation of the CCP.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very lax and very intersting. The professor is very passionate about teaching about Chinese history, especially with the history of Mao Zedong
reviews.comment_grading: Very good grading, just go to class and easy to get B
reviews.comment_workload: Very low, each week has a forum that you need to only post one talking point. Had a book report but was a short book to read.

reviews.author: alexchw
reviews.title: Don't expect too much on the grading
reviews.comment_content:
Normal...
Will be good if you like studying history and getting others' ideas.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is knowledgeable but he depends on the  (his) readings too much, so the teaching mainly depends on the content of reading. You will know nothing if you have not read or just read very little. One thing is good, he will provide study guide.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading system is pretty clear
5% - attendance (will be graded through IPRS quiz)
15% - Weekly timeline/chronology x 10
30% - Mid-term exam
5% - Oral History report outline+timeline    
20% - Oral History report
I get slightly below mean in mt and 75% of the final score and finally B.
I would say I expect the better grade under the terrible workload, so it is a bit disappointing one.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is completely disastrous. Although this is just 1000 level course, the workload is like 4000-course, so please try to avoid it if you are not interested in history and assigment.

reviews.author: Andy Tam
reviews.comment_content: The course mainly focuses on the history of East Asia from the 19th to the 20th century (especially China, Japan, and Korean). The lecturer shared spectacular personal experience and showed plenty of historical videos and photos. The classes are full of content and you will not be bored with attending the class if you are interested in history.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecturer gave positive responses during the class discussion and a lot of interaction with the students. Both of the lecturer and TAs acquire comprehensive knowledge about the history and related incidents.
reviews.comment_grading: If you want to aim A range, you better submit the documentary. I think I scored at least 85% and got B+ eventually without submitting the documentary.
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of required readings and in-class discussion about them but no penalty for not reading them. However, some of the contents from the readings had covered in the exam. Midterm, final, creative essay, interview with people who involved in a special historical incident, history timeline and a documentary video(optional).For the video, you can do it in a group of 2-3 or individual. IPRS also is required for attendance.
